text: Introduction
label: HH1

text: Severe acute respiratory syndrome-coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV2) emerged in Wuhan, China, in November
label: BODY

text: 2019. By October 2020, this virus had resulted in more than 41.5 million cases of COVID-19 and 1 million
label: BODY

text: deaths. The majority of COVID-19 cases currently being reported are predominantly in developed countries,
label: BODY

text: such as the United States, Brazil, Russia, and France. Despite the increasing number of models and stud-
label: BODY

text: ies on COVID-19, there is very little information available to inform humanitarian response interventions,
label: BODY

text: the need for which may be unprecedented, particularly where infrastructure is lacking to effectively prevent
label: BODY

text: spread of transmission and treat affected patients.
label: BODY

text: In late 2019, the United Nations (UN) Ofﬁce for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) Centre
label: BODY

text: for Humanitarian Data created a new workstream for predictive analytics. This was based on demand from
label: BODY

text: OCHA’s leadership to “use data, and especially the tools of predictive analytics to get ahead, to be more an-
label: BODY

text: ticipatory, to predict what is about to happen and to trigger the response earlier.” This ambition aligns with
label: BODY

text: the overall goal of the Centre, which is to increase the use and impact of data in the humanitarian sector.
label: BODY

text: The COVID-19 pandemic has brought into stark focus the need for data and the value of models to inform
label: BODY

text: response strategies. Anticipatory action is no longer an abstract idea but something populations are actively
label: BODY

text: doing by staying home and increasing the number of hospital beds to protect the most vulnerable popula-
label: BODY

text: tions.
label: BODY

text: Epidemic forecasting is one tool through which we can gain an understanding of the ﬁnal outbreak size
label: BODY

text: and indicators of when the COVID-19 epidemic peaks in a country. This provides decision-makers with the
label: BODY

text: capability to plan, surge, and manage resources during a pandemic. UN OCHA and the Johns Hopkins Uni-
label: BODY

text: versity Applied Physics Laboratory have therefore established a partnership to inform COVID-19 strategies
label: BODY

text: for humanitarian interventions by both national authorities and the humanitarian community in selected
label: BODY

text: high-priority countries, resulting in increased technical capacity to predict new and compounded humani-
label: BODY

text: tarian needs, and use of data science to arrive at interventions to mitigate them.
label: BODY

text: This partnership developed a series of adjustments to a novel COVID-19 model (JHUAPL-Bucky) that in-
label: BODY

text: corporates different vulnerability factors to provide insights on the scale of the crisis in priority countries
label: BODY

text: at national and sub-national levels, how different response interventions are expected to impact the epi-
label: BODY

text: demic curve, and the duration of the crisis in speciﬁc locations. The resultant model (OCHA-Bucky) strati-
label: BODY

text: ﬁes COVID-19 dynamics by age and population vulnerability. Input to the model consists of geographically
label: BODY

text: distributed COVID-19 cases and deaths, as well as attributes such as inter-regional mobility, population vul-
label: BODY

text: nerability, nonpharmaceutical interventions (NPIs) , and social contact matrices. Model output consists of
label: BODY

text: future projections of these same quantities, as well as severe cases (deﬁned as a proportion of total cases).
label: BODY

text: The model considers both inter-regional mobility of the population and time-varying NPIs. OCHA-Bucky has
label: BODY

text: been used to provide weekly projections to six OCHA country ofﬁces: Afghanistan, the Democratic Republic
label: BODY

text: of Congo, Iraq, Somalia, Sudan, and South Sudan.
label: BODY

text: The results of this model, when applied in the context of the United States, have been included in the Centers
label: BODY

text: for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) COVID-19 Mathematical Modeling Forecasting Ensemble [1]. Here,
label: BODY

text: we detail the modiﬁcations of the JHUAPL-Bucky model used to shift results to the context of countries in
label: BODY

text: receipt of humanitarian aid.
label: BODY

text: A number of critical complementary components must be modiﬁed in order to perform accurate disease
label: BODY

text: modeling within this context. Namely, these include:
label: BODY

text: • Estimating disease parameters;
label: BODY

text: • Acquiring data sources that accurately reﬂect both the current and historical states of the outbreak;
label: BODY

text: • Estimating mobility within a country;
label: BODY

text: • Estimating the impact of secondary/tertiary factors on the vulnerability of a given population;
label: BODY

text: • Estimations of the effects of measures taken by individuals and governments to curb the spread of
label: BODY

text: the disease; and
label: BODY

text: The Centre for Humanitarian Data centre.humdata.org | Join our mailing list: bit.ly/humdatamailing | Twitter: @humdata | Email: centrehumdata@un.org 3
label: BODY

text: • Estimations of the effects of the above at both the sub-national and national levels.
label: BODY

text: The following sections describe the OCHA-Bucky model in detail. Section 2.1 gives an overview of the model
label: BODY

text: and its components. Further details related to parameter estimation, data sourcing, and model initialization
label: BODY

text: are given in Sections 2.2 and 2.3, respectively. Section 3 details the model input and output. Lastly, this model
label: BODY

text: is publicly available; details about how to access the model as well as the corresponding documentation
label: BODY

text: are given in Section 4.
label: BODY

text: Model Description
label: HH1

text: The JHUAPL-Bucky model is a COVID-19 metapopulation compartment model initially designed to estimate
label: BODY

text: medium-term (on the order of weeks) case incidence and healthcare usage at the second administrative
label: BODY

text: (admin-2, ADM2) level (counties in the United States; cities or districts in various countries). These ADM2
label: BODY

text: regions are all coupled using mobility information to approximate the inter- and intra-regional contacts be-
label: BODY

text: tween the members of the populations. Using the historical case and death data, local demographic data,
label: BODY

text: and a set of parameters derived from empirical studies (Section 2.2.1), the model infers a number of local-
label: BODY

text: ized features (given in Table 1) that are related to the spread of COVID-19. Projecting forward in time, Bucky
label: BODY

text: then uses an age-stratiﬁed compartment model to estimate the case load as well as provide outputs relating
label: BODY

text: to the healthcare burden of each locality. These time forecasts are performed numerous times (Monte Carlo
label: BODY

text: experiments), with each individual simulation using minor modiﬁcations to the input parameters at random,
label: BODY

text: scaled to the uncertainty of the estimates. The resulting collection of simulations is then used to obtain
label: BODY

text: probabilistic estimates for all output variables. A fork of JHUAPL-Bucky, the OCHA-Bucky model, addition-
label: BODY

text: ally includes a set of new features to properly handle the unique aspects of epidemic modeling in countries
label: BODY

text: beyond the United States. To this end, the OCHA-Bucky model includes a series of factors related to the
label: BODY

text: relative vulnerability of local populations.
label: BODY

text: Model Overview
label: H2

text: At its base, the OCHA-Bucky model is a spatially distributed SEIR model. SEIR models are a class of determin-
label: BODY

text: istic models used to demonstrate how infectious diseases that are spread by person-to-person transmission
label: BODY

text: in a population. The simplest versions of such models are systems of ordinary differential equations and
label: BODY

text: are analysed mathematically [2].
label: BODY

text: Within the context of an SEIR model, disease dynamics are modeled over time by moving the population
label: BODY

text: through a series of compartments (otherwise known as "bins" or "states"). Those states are as follows:
label: BODY

text: • Susceptible (S): the fraction of the population that could be potentially subjected to the infection;
label: BODY

text: • Exposed (E): the fraction of the population that has been infected but does not show symptoms yet;
label: BODY

text: • Infectious (I): the fraction of the population that is infective after the latent period;
label: BODY

text: • Recovered (R): the fraction of the population that has been infected and recovered from the infection.
label: BODY

text: The total population is represented by the sum of the compartments. Basic assumptions of this type of
label: BODY

text: model:
label: BODY

text: • Once the model is initialized, no individuals are added to the susceptible group. It follows that births
label: BODY

text: and natural deaths are unaccounted for, migration into and out of the region is frozen for the duration
label: BODY

text: of a simulation, and none of the population has been vaccinated or is immune to the pathogen;
label: BODY

text: • The population within each strata is uniform, and each pair of individuals within the strata are equally
label: BODY

text: likely to interact;
label: BODY

text: • The probability of interaction between individuals in the population is not rare;
label: BODY

text: • Once infected, an individual cannot be reinfected with the virus.
label: BODY

text: The Centre for Humanitarian Data centre.humdata.org | Join our mailing list: bit.ly/humdatamailing | Twitter: @humdata | Email: centrehumdata@un.org 4
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: Eij
label: BODY

text: Ihosp
label: BODY

text: Imild
label: BODY

text: Iasym
label: BODY

text: Rij
label: BODY

text: Rhosp
label: BODY

text: Dij
label: BODY

text: βij
label: BODY

text: (1 −α)ηi(νj)σ
label: BODY

text: α(1 −ηi(νj))σ
label: BODY

text: (1 −φi)γ
label: BODY

text: φiγ
label: BODY

text: Figure 1: Model Diagram. See Table 1 for a description of the compartments and transition parameters. Note
label: BODY

text: that the compartments E, Iasym, Imild, Ihosp and Rhosp are gamma-distributed with shape parameters speciﬁed
label: BODY

text: in the conﬁguration ﬁle.
label: BODY

text: The OCHA-Bucky model consists of a collection of coupled and stratiﬁed SEIR models. Since COVID-19
label: BODY

text: exhibits heavily age-dependent properties, wherein a majority of severe cases are in older individuals, SEIR
label: BODY

text: models are stratiﬁed via the age demographic structure of a geographic region to obtain accurate estimates
label: BODY

text: of case severity and deaths. Additionally, to model the spatial dynamics of COVID spread, we consider a set
label: BODY

text: of SEIR sub-models at the smallest geographic level for which we have appropriate data. (See Section 2.3
label: BODY

text: for a discussion of available data.)
label: BODY

text: The basic structure of the model is displayed in Figure 1. Age is denoted by index i, and geographic regions
label: BODY

text: are denoted by index j. Within each strata, OCHA-Bucky models the susceptible and exposed populations,
label: BODY

text: followed by one of three possible infected states: asymptomatic (Iasym), mild (Imild), and severe (Ihosp). Mem-
label: BODY

text: bers of the population who are either asymptomatic or exhibit mild symptoms recover from the virus at a
label: BODY

text: rate γ. Those who exhibit severe symptoms and are in need of healthcare support will either recover after a
label: BODY

text: period of illness at rate 1/τi or expire as a result of the virus at rate φiγ.
label: BODY

text: A critical component of the OCHA-Bucky model is the parameterization of the model (Section 2.2). A number
label: BODY

text: of parameters must be derived and/or estimated from their original data sources. These include, but are not
label: BODY

text: limited to, those listed in Table 1 as well as local estimates of local case doubling time, case reporting rate,
label: BODY

text: case fatality rate, and case hospitalization rate. Further details of these quantities as well as how they are
label: BODY

text: estimated are given in Section 2.2. All parameter estimation for the model includes the basic assumption
label: BODY

text: that, once estimated and initialized, these parameters remain constant during the simulation period.
label: BODY

text: Coupling individual age and geographically stratiﬁed sub-models occurs across a number of dimensions
label: BODY

text: including disease state and pre-existing vulnerability. Sub-models are coupled together using both the spa-
label: BODY

text: tial mobility matrix (see Section 2.3.3) and age-based contact matrices (see Section 2.3.5). Modeling of the
label: BODY

text: overall interaction rates between geographic locations and age groups is an important component in ac-
label: BODY

text: curately modeling non-pharmaceutical Interventions (NPIs). OCHA-Bucky accounts for the implementation
label: BODY

text: of NPIs (e.g., school closures, border closures, face mask wearing) via modifying either the social contact
label: BODY

text: matrices or the basic reproductive number, R0. Further details are given in Section 2.3.6.
label: BODY

text: Together, these components contribute to a model that is adaptable to a number of contexts. OCHA-Bucky
label: BODY

text: is calibrated to the uncertainties in the case data and the disease parameters, leading to a model that is
label: BODY

text: robust to the quality and resolution of available input data.
label: BODY

text: The Centre for Humanitarian Data centre.humdata.org | Join our mailing list: bit.ly/humdatamailing | Twitter: @humdata | Email: centrehumdata@un.org 5

text: Model Parameterization
label: BODY

text: Disease/Healthcare Parameters
label: BODY

text: The CDC has published pandemic planning scenarios [3] that contain recommended parameters describing
label: BODY

text: biological and epidemiological factors. Of these ﬁve planning scenarios, OCHA-Bucky uses scenario ﬁve,
label: BODY

text: which contains the CDC’s current best estimates for disease severity and transmission. These parameters
label: BODY

text: are described in detail, based on information available from the CDC, and summarized in Table 2.
label: BODY

text: The Centre for Humanitarian Data centre.humdata.org | Join our mailing list: bit.ly/humdatamailing | Twitter: @humdata | Email: centrehumdata@un.org 6

text: Disease Transmission
label: BODY

text: The following parameters describe the transmissibility of the virus. The percentage of infections that are
label: BODY

text: asymptomatic (α) refers to the percentage of infections that will never develop symptoms. This is a difﬁcult
label: BODY

text: parameter to estimate due to logistical complications (individuals would need to be tested to ensure they
label: BODY

text: remain asymptomatic while infectious) and because the level of asymptomatic infections varies by age.
label: BODY

text: The best estimate for this parameter is the midpoint between the lower bound of [4], the upper bound of [5],
label: BODY

text: which corresponds to the estimates from [6].
label: BODY

text: The relative infectiousness of asymptomatic individuals compared to symptomatic individuals (rel_inf_asym)
label: BODY

text: is calculated using upper and lower bounds on the difference in viral dynamics between asymptomatic and
label: BODY

text: symptomatic cases. The lower bound is derived from data indicating that more severe cases have higher
label: BODY

text: viral loads [7] and a study that indicates symptomatic cases shed for longer and have higher viral loads
label: BODY

text: than asymptomatic cases [8]. Other studies indicate that both symptomatic and asymptomatic cases have
label: BODY

text: similar duration and viral shedding [9], which is used as the upper bound.
label: BODY

text: The ﬁnal parameter relating to disease transmission is the fraction of transmission prior to symptom onset
label: BODY

text: (frac_trans_before_sym), which corresponds to the percentage of new cases caused by transmission from
label: BODY

text: an individual before they become symptomatic. The lower bound is derived from [10], with the upper bound
label: BODY

text: derived from [11].
label: BODY

text: The Centre for Humanitarian Data centre.humdata.org | Join our mailing list: bit.ly/humdatamailing | Twitter: @humdata | Email: centrehumdata@un.org 7
label: BODY

text: Disease Characteristics and Severity
label: BODY

text: The mean serial interval, Ts, is the time in days from exposure to onset of symptoms and is taken from [12].
label: BODY

text: The mean generation interval, Tg, is the period of time (in days) between symptom onset for one individual
label: BODY

text: and symptom onset for a person they have infected. This value is from [10].
label: BODY

text: The case fatality ratio (CFR) is the number of individuals who will die of the disease; the case hospitalization-
label: BODY

text: severity ratio (CHR) corresponds to the number of cases that are severe and necessitate hospitalization.
label: BODY

text: Within the context of the United States, this ratio corresponds to the individuals admitted to a hospital. In a
label: BODY

text: context where access to medical care is limited, this ratio corresponds to the ratio of individuals who exhibit
label: BODY

text: severe disease symptoms.
label: BODY

text: Hospital-related parameters are derived using data from COVID-Net [13] and the CDC’s Data Collation and
label: BODY

text: Integration for Public Health Event Response (DCIPHER). All data is taken from the period between March
label: BODY

text: 1, 2020 to July 15, 2020 unless otherwise noted. The time it takes from symptom onset to hospitalization
label: BODY

text: in days is denoted by I_to_H_time. The number of days an individual will be hospitalized is H_TIME. Finally,
label: BODY

text: the number of days between death and reporting is D_REPORT_TIME.
label: BODY

text: Approximated and Derived Parameters
label: BODY

text: Unless otherwise noted, the model parameters that are derived from input parameters1 and the historical
label: BODY

text: data are estimated as the average value across the entire population of a region (i.e., they are not age-
label: BODY

text: stratiﬁed). This limitation results from having a lack of age-stratiﬁed historical case and death data in most
label: BODY

text: regions. Additionally, some parameters are only derived at the national (ADM0) level due to sparse reporting
label: BODY

text: at the sub-national level (see footnotes).
label: BODY

text: • Local mean Case Fatality Ratio, φj;
label: BODY

text: We must begin by estimating the local overall CFR for each region based on the local demographics.
label: BODY

text: Since the fatality rate for COVID-19 is highly age dependent, this overall CFR will vary dramatically
label: BODY

text: between region with different age structure [15]. By contracting the CFR as a function of age with the
label: BODY

text: local age demographics of each region, we can obtain the region overall estimate for the CFR,
label: BODY

text: φj = φiNij.
label: BODY

text: • Case Reporting Rate, ρj;
label: BODY

text: In order to estimate the local fraction of COVID-19 cases that are reported in the historical data, OCHA-
label: BODY

text: Bucky uses a method similar to Russel et al. [16] based on the deviation from the expected CFR. Using
label: BODY

text: the derived CFR and the historical case and death data, the OCHA-Bucky model ﬁrst estimates the
label: BODY

text: overall case reporting rate for symptomatic cases at the ADM2 level. This is done using the assumption
label: BODY

text: that the ratio of the expected CFR for each region based on the local demographics, φj to the CFR
label: BODY

text: calculated from the cumulative historical data, φhist
label: BODY

text: 2 i.e.
label: BODY

text: ρj =
label: BODY

text: φhist
label: BODY

text: = φiNij
label: BODY

text: φhist
label: BODY

text: In calculating φdata
label: BODY

text: , a lag in the reporting of deaths equal to the given input parameter is assumed ??.
label: BODY

text: The estimated case reporting rate for each of the last X number of days is then calculated; the mean
label: BODY

text: value in each region is used.
label: BODY

text: • Doubling Time, TD;
label: BODY

text: 1Throughout our discussion in this section we make use of Einstein notation[14] to describe the mathematics. This is owed to the
label: BODY

text: fact that most of the variables are tensors by virtue of the fact that they are stratiﬁed in multiple ways (e.g., age and locality)
label: BODY

text: Most importantly, we use the notation of a tensor contraction to represent the summed multiplication along an axis. i.e. cixi =
label: BODY

text: i cixi for all indices that appear as both upper and lower indices in a single term but are otherwise undeﬁned.
label: BODY

text: 2In OCHA-Bucky, the the value is the CFR derived from the historical data, φhist
label: BODY

text: is estimated at the the country level from the WHO
label: BODY

text: country level case/death history and used uniformly throughout all sub-regions. This is done to circumvent potential data issues present
label: BODY

text: in the local case data in various countries.
label: BODY

text: The Centre for Humanitarian Data centre.humdata.org | Join our mailing list: bit.ly/humdatamailing | Twitter: @humdata | Email: centrehumdata@un.org 8
label: BODY

text: Rather then explicitly include a parameter controlling the transmission rate, Bucky uses the recent
label: BODY

text: historical data to estimate transmission at the local level 3. The local doubling time TD,j is estimated
label: BODY

text: by ﬁrst considering the historical data prior to the date in which the simulation will begin. Historical
label: BODY

text: data is used to calculate the doubling time for the seven days prior to simulation. These historical
label: BODY

text: doubling times are then averaged to yield the value of TD,j for a particular simulation. Once these
label: BODY

text: values are calculated, methods similar to those described in [17] can be used to estimate the latent
label: BODY

text: period, 1/σ, infectious period, 1/γ, as well as an estimate of the effective R0 value. These methods
label: BODY

text: also yield the shape parameters of the gamma-distributions corresponding to E, Iasym, Imild, and Ihosp
label: BODY

text: compartments.
label: BODY

text: • Case Hospitalization Ratio with Vulnerability, ηi(νj);
label: BODY

text: To account for the inclusion of the vulnerability index in OCHA-Bucky, we rescale the population frac-
label: BODY

text: tion requiring healthcare support (the CHR, ηi) based on the local fraction of vulnerable population,
label: BODY

text: νj:
label: BODY

text: ηi(νj) = (1 −νj)ηi + V νjηi
label: BODY

text: where V is the relative severity among the vulnerable population (See 2.3.2 for how this is estimated).
label: BODY

text: • Contact rate between susceptible and infected individuals, βij;
label: BODY

text: The quantity βij represents the average number of contacts per person per time, multiplied by the prob-
label: BODY

text: ability of disease transmission in a contact between a susceptible and an infectious subject. Within
label: BODY

text: Bucky, this consists of the rate that an individual in age group i in location j gets infected by the virus.
label: BODY

text: This depends on three quantities:
label: BODY

text: 1. The infectivity rate of the virus;
label: BODY

text: 2. The average contact between someone from age group i and individuals across all other age
label: BODY

text: groups;
label: BODY

text: 3. The average rate of mobility into location j from across all other locations in the simulation.
label: BODY

text: Data Sources
label: BODY

text: Population Data
label: BODY

text: In order to estimate the age- and sex-disaggregated population for each ADM2 region two different datasets
label: BODY

text: are combined:
label: BODY

text: • Administrative boundaries shapeﬁles at the ADM2 level from the Humanitarian Data Exchange (HDX);
label: BODY

text: • United Nations -adjusted WorldPop age and sex disaggregated population raster data.
label: BODY

text: Input consists of raster data with the administrative region polygons for the province/state (ADM1) and
label: BODY

text: district/county (ADM2) to get total populations for each region, stratiﬁed by age and sex. Then, values are
label: BODY

text: scaled so that the total population is consistent with the regional UN-adjusted population.
label: BODY

text: Vulnerability Parameters
label: BODY

text: The fraction of the population in an ADM2 region that is particularly vulnerable to COVID-19 is estimated by
label: BODY

text: calculating the proportion of the population effected by those factors described in Sections 2.3.2.1 – 2.3.2.4.
label: BODY

text: To avoid confounding factors contributing to a population’s increased vulnerability, we select the maximum
label: BODY

text: of these proportions and consider this to be the proportion of the population that is at increased vulnerability
label: BODY

text: to the effects of COVID-19. Those in the population that are considered vulnerable have a higher risk of a
label: BODY

text: severe case or death (and hence a higher CHR and CFR) than non-vulnerable members of a region. Given
label: BODY

text: literature estimates, the vulnerable population is given a CHR that is 1.5 times greater than the average CHR
label: BODY

text: of a region (calculated via age and gender demographic information). 4
label: BODY

text: 3In OCHA-Bucky, this estimation if performed at the nation level using WHO case data, similar to the estimation of reported CFR.
label: BODY

text: 4The CFR carries the CHR scalar multiplication forward since CFR is estimated as a proportion of those with severe cases.
label: BODY

text: The Centre for Humanitarian Data centre.humdata.org | Join our mailing list: bit.ly/humdatamailing | Twitter: @humdata | Email: centrehumdata@un.org 9
label: BODY

text: Urban/Rural disaggregation
label: BODY

text: Although not a risk factor on its own, there are several vulnerabilities that scale differently with urban and
label: BODY

text: rural populations. The COVID-19 crisis has impacted urban areas signiﬁcantly more than rural areas, due
label: BODY

text: primarily to mobility and proximity to other ADM2 regions, which increase transmission rates. Urban/rural
label: BODY

text: stratiﬁcation is available in raster format from WorldPop. To calculate the urban-rural fraction for each ADM2
label: BODY

text: region, data is taken from Global Human Settlement Layer. Based on the classiﬁcations available in [18]
label: BODY

text: anything denser than suburban (class 21 or above) is considered to be urban, and the rest to be rural.
label: BODY

text: Food insecurity
label: BODY

text: There is evidence that weight impacts the severity of inﬂuenza and other respiratory viruses [19]. We have
label: BODY

text: used food security as an indicator of population weight and other factors that effect the populations base-
label: BODY

text: line ability to respond to respiratory illness. Hence, we scale our our vulnerability factor, νj by levels of food
label: BODY

text: security within the region. Food insecurity data is obtained from the Integrated Food Security Phase Clas-
label: BODY

text: siﬁcation (IPC) Global Platform. The proportion of individuals living in regions at IPC level 3 or greater are
label: BODY

text: considered at-risk. The data tend to have a mix of information at the ADM1 and ADM2 levels; the most
label: BODY

text: granular data is utilized for this calculation.
label: BODY

text: Indoor air pollution - indoor cooking fuels
label: BODY

text: The use of indoor cooking fuels is a risk factor for COVID-19 whose prevalence depends on an urban or rural
label: BODY

text: setting. Data on the use of solid fuels is obtained from the World Health Organization. The total fraction of
label: BODY

text: the population using solid fuels is calculated by re-scaling at each location the urban/rural estimates from
label: BODY

text: WHO by the corresponding urban/rural population fraction estimated according to 2.3.2.1. There is evidence
label: BODY

text: linking indoor air pollution and respiratory illness [20]. Based on the available literature, we estimated that
label: BODY

text: those that used solid cooking fuels are 1.8 times more likely to develop a severe infection.
label: BODY

text: Medical comorbidities
label: BODY

text: Medical co-morbidities, such as diabetes, cardiovascular disease, and tuberculosis, were considered as pos-
label: BODY

text: sible additional vulnerability parameters for cases and deaths. However, the OCHA-Bucky model does not
label: BODY

text: use these parameters, as they are highly correlated with age and gender, and have little additional impact
label: BODY

text: on vulnerability and death rate estimates.
label: BODY

text: Mobility Data and Matrix Generation
label: BODY

text: A required input of the model is the amount of interaction that occurs between different regions at the sub-
label: BODY

text: national level. Mobility matrix data is used to simulate disease spread across different administrative units
label: BODY

text: of a country. The JHUAPL-Bucky model assumes contact between various regions through using a combi-
label: BODY

text: nation of various sources of cell-phone based mobility estimates. In the OCHA-Bucky model, due to a lack
label: BODY

text: of mobile phone based estimates, contact between ADM2 regions is approximated through an analysis of
label: BODY

text: road network data.
label: BODY

text: Road density data from Humanitarian OpenStreetMap (HOTOSM) is used to estimate the strength of the
label: BODY

text: connection between all ADM2 regions considered. To create the mobility matrix using roads data, a roads
label: BODY

text: shapeﬁle is read, and roads that intersect with at least one ADM2 border are kept. For each road, a list is
label: BODY

text: then created of which ADM2 regions the road passes through. Completing this gives a list of region to re-
label: BODY

text: gion pairs, for which geographic distance (between ADM2 geographic centroids) and road connectivity are
label: BODY

text: calculated. To calculate road connectivity, road network lines are obtained from HOTOSM on HDX. The road
label: BODY

text: classiﬁcation system from HOTOSM is used to apply weights for each road type, calculated by multiplying
label: BODY

text: the estimated typical speed and number of lanes for each road class; connectivity is deﬁned as the sum of
label: BODY

text: all roads connecting the region pair.
label: BODY

text: Road connectivity, the motor vehicle ownership fraction, and the reciprocal geographic distance between
label: BODY

text: regions are all then multiplied together to give estimates of connectivity between ADM2 pairs. Adjacent
label: BODY

text: regions with many large road connections necessarily have higher connectivity values than those which
label: BODY

text: have few small or even no road connections. Long-range or non-adjacent interactions between regions are
label: BODY

text: also considered, especially in cases where a road crosses more than two regional boundaries. However,
label: BODY

text: the diminishing weakness of non-adjacent ADM2 pairs is captured through the reciprocal of the geographic
label: BODY

text: The Centre for Humanitarian Data centre.humdata.org | Join our mailing list: bit.ly/humdatamailing | Twitter: @humdata | Email: centrehumdata@un.org 10
label: BODY

text: centroids; higher values indicate closer regions.
label: BODY

text: Within the model, the probability of the disease to spread from one ADM2 region to another is proportional
label: BODY

text: to the estimated weights in the mobility matrix.
label: BODY

text: COVID-19 Cases and Deaths
label: BODY

text: Sub-national historical daily number of COVID-19 cases are obtained from HDX. In most countries of interest,
label: BODY

text: the source for COVID case counts is the nation’s Ministry of Public Health. Additional federal (ADM0) histor-
label: BODY

text: ical data is also obtained from the WHO. Data is usually available at the ADM1 level. To obtain ADM2-level
label: BODY

text: case counts, ADM1 case counts are scaled using the ADM2 population.
label: BODY

text: Contact Matrix
label: BODY

text: Contact matrices quantify how much people from different age groups interact, and are extracted from Prem
label: BODY

text: et al. [21]. The contact matrices used are taken from the home, school, work, and other locations. For some
label: BODY

text: countries, the contact matrix is not directly available. In these instances, a country in the same region and
label: BODY

text: with similar socioeconomic indicators is used as a proxy.5
label: BODY

text: Non-pharmaceutical Interventions (NPIs)
label: BODY

text: NPIs are mitigations, apart from getting vaccinated and taking medicine, that people and communities can
label: BODY

text: take to help slow the spread of communicable diseases. As a vaccine for COVID-19 has yet to be deployed,
label: BODY

text: NPIs are among the the best strategies for controlling the spread of the current COVID-19 virus. The struc-
label: BODY

text: ture of the OCHA-Bucky model allows for the incorporation of NPIs via the modiﬁcation of a combination
label: BODY

text: of the following : the basic reproduction number, local contact matrices, and inter-regional mobility matrices.
label: BODY

text: For each country an initial list of NPIs was obtained from the ACAPS COVID-19 Government Measures
label: BODY

text: Dataset. This dataset is complemented with additional qualitative information from in-country stakeholders.
label: BODY

text: The estimated compliance level are tailored to speciﬁc countries.
label: BODY

text: Implementation of Nonpharmaceutical Interventions
label: BODY

text: NPIs are categorized and implemented in OCHA-Bucky based on their classiﬁcation into three categories:
label: BODY

text: 1. Contact-Matrix Based NPIs;
label: BODY

text: These NPIs are those that effect only certain age groups within the total population. These NPI effect
label: BODY

text: the ratios relating the components of the contact matrices. The NPI that fall under this category are:
label: BODY

text: • School closure
label: BODY

text: • Shielding elderly
label: BODY

text: 2. Mobility Based NPI;
label: BODY

text: This classiﬁcation is for those NPI that lead to changes in mobility/movement between administra-
label: BODY

text: tive districts (as opposed to movement within an administrative district). The NPI that fall under this
label: BODY

text: category are :
label: BODY

text: • Closing of borders, ports, and/or international ﬂights
label: BODY

text: • Restricting inter-regional movement
label: BODY

text: 3. Reproduction Number Based NPI;
label: BODY

text: This classiﬁcation is for those NPI that have an effect on the overall scaling of transmissibility. It
label: BODY

text: encompasses both intra-regional measures to reduce transmission as well as national level initiatives
label: BODY

text: designed to reduce transmission throughout the country. The NPI that fall under this category are :
label: BODY

text: • Social distancing;
label: BODY

text: 5The model from The London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine also utilizes this strategy.
label: BODY

text: The Centre for Humanitarian Data centre.humdata.org | Join our mailing list: bit.ly/humdatamailing | Twitter: @humdata | Email: centrehumdata@un.org 11
label: BODY

text: • Face mask wearing;
label: BODY

text: • Installation of hand washing stations;
label: BODY

text: • Reduction of size of public gatherings;
label: BODY

text: • Closing businesses;
label: BODY

text: • Partial lockdown;
label: BODY

text: • Awareness campaigns (e.g., vaccination programs).
label: BODY

text: A summary of the NPIs that are currently implemented in OCHA-Bucky are given in Table 3. This table in-
label: BODY

text: cludes the classiﬁcation, effects, and sources that are currently being used to approximate the effects of
label: BODY

text: various NPI.
label: BODY

text: With the current implementation, we have the ability to distinguish between the effects of NPI within the
label: BODY

text: categories mentioned above. For the case in which multiple NPI within category III are implemented, we
label: BODY

text: have implemented a value-added approach to calculating their effectiveness in reducing the basic repro-
label: BODY

text: duction number. In this case, we calculate the reduction in R0 based on the number of NPIs in place. If 1 NPI
label: BODY

text: is in place, R0 is reduced by 40%. If 2 NPI are in place, R0 is reduced by 60%. If 3 or more NPI are in place,
label: BODY

text: then R0 is reduced by 70%.
label: BODY

label: HH3

text: Model Initialization and Output
label: HH1

text: Using the data sources and methods described in Sections 2.2 and 2.3, we are able to both estimate values
label: BODY

text: of parameters initialize the values of all the compartments in the model on the last date of the historical
label: BODY

text: data. This will serve as the initial state of our simulation.
label: BODY

text: As output, OCHA-Bucky generates one data ﬁle per Monte Carlo run. The ﬁles contain data at the ADM2
label: BODY

text: level and are indexed by data and run ID. This data is post-processed to combine data across all the dates
label: BODY

text: and simulations. It can then be aggregated at desired geographic levels. A separate ﬁle is created for each
label: BODY

text: administrative level, with each row indexed by date, admin ID, and quantile. The columns of this output ﬁle
label: BODY

text: are described in Table 4.
label: BODY

text: Model Open Source Code and Documentation
label: HH1

text: Further documentation and resources can be found in the following locations.
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: – The JHUAPL-Bucky model is available on Github at https://github.com/mattkinsey/bucky.
label: BODY

text: – Documentation for JHUAPL-Bucky is available at https://docs.buckymodel.com/en/stable/.
label: BODY

text: • For the latest resources on the international version of the model (OCHA-Bucky) :
label: BODY
